H0.text: Linear eukaryotic chromosomes differ from prokaryotic chromosomes, which are circular.

H1.text: Multiple eukaryotic chromosomes are unlike prokaryotic chromosomes.

H2.text: Eukaryotic chromosomes are simple, unlike prokaryotic chromosomes.

H3.text: Expanding is what eukaryotic chromosomes are, unlike prokaryotic chromosomes.

A4.text: In most eukaryotic cells, DNA is arranged in multiple linear chromosomes. In contrast, most prokaryotic cells generally contain a singular circular chromosome.

A5.text: Borrelia burgdorferi was the first bacterium to be found to have a linear chromosome, but new examples, such as various Streptomyces and Coxiella burnetii, have been found.

A6.text: In yeast and plants, the shape of mtDNA depends on life-cycle. During some points they may be circular, but during others a linear branched shape is found, consisting of concatenated copies of the original genome.

A7.text: Maize seedlings have Chloroplast DNA (cpDNA) mostly in a branched linear form.
